Exponential sums

Dec 22, 2019

In the last post, I talked about one of the projects I worked on for 18.821 this semester. In this post, I’d like to talk about another one, which I worked on under Roman Bezrukavnikov. Most of this stuff only uses elementary algebraic geometry. The interested reader should also consult Eisenbud-Harris and Roman’s MathOverflow question.

We’ll be interested in the following question: when is , and hence , independent of for generic ? One would like to apply the Weil conjectures to answer this question, but in order to do so, the hyperplane section must a smooth projective variety. Even if is smooth, this hyperplane section will not always be smooth, since the hyperplane may not intersect transversely. In order to utilize the Weil conjectures, we therefore need to ensure that is such that intersects transversally. Let us call this assumption .

We’ll use the weak and hard Lefschetz hyperplane theorems to show that if is a smooth projective variety of dimension whose dual variety is not a hypersurface, then , and hence , is independent of for generic . Returning to the general case, it follows that it remains to understand the middle-dimensional cohomology , as is typical in all flavors of geometry. The question of when is independent of for generic can now be reduced to the question of when is independent of for generic . Obviously, one such case would be when the map is an isomorphism, i.e., when the weak Lefschetz theorem extends to the middle cohomology of the hyperplane section. This will not always be the case, but we can nonetheless provide general conditions on when this result would hold.

So: we’ve reduced to understanding when the middle dimensional cohomology of a hyperplane section of does not depend on the hyperplane itself. One of our main results shows that this is the case when the dual variety of is not a hypersurface (at least when has dimension ). The question of when the dual variety is not a hypersurface was studied in great detail here; we shall take a more elementary approach in this section.

We begin with by recalling some basics. If is a smooth projective variety, then the dual variety of is the set of hyperplanes such that is singular. Our main source of examples for when the weak Lefschetz theorem extends to the middle cohomology of the hyperplane section comes from the following:

Theorem: Let is a smooth projective variety of dimension , and suppose that is not a hypersurface. If is a hyperplane such that the hyperplane section is smooth, then the map is an isomorphism.

The proof we present of this theorem only uses the weak Lefschetz theorem combined with the Leray spectral sequence. There is an alternative proof of this result, suggested to us by Roman Bezrukavnikov; this argument relies on (elementary aspects of) the theory of perverse sheaves, but we do not present it here.

Note that the statement of this theorem is not an if-and-only-if; namely, the map being an isomorphism for all hyperplanes does not imply that is not a hypersurface. For instance, we shall find below that the image of the -fold Veronese embedding satisfies the conclusion of the theorem, but its dual variety is a hypersurface.

It is quite unlikely that the dual variety of a smooth projective variety is not a hypersurface. Nonetheless, we have the following examples. One expects the dual variety to a variety to not be a hypersurface if is “constant in the vertical direction”. This is made precise by the notion of a scroll. Recall that a (smooth) -dimensional scroll is a variety which is the union of a one-parameter family of -planes contained in . In other words, a scroll is a smooth -dimensional variety with a surjective morphism to a smooth curve such that the fiber over every point is isomorphic to .

For instance, the Segre embedding evidently defines a smooth -dimensional scroll in . Another example: a two-dimensional scroll is a ruled surface. Quadric surfaces provide examples of ruled surfaces (at least, over a finite field). Since an -dimensional scroll is a union of a one-parameter family of -planes, one expects the dual variety to to not be a hypersurface.

This indeed turns out to be the case: if is a smooth -dimensional scroll with , then satisfies the hypotheses of the theorem, i.e., the dual variety is not a hypersurface. Again, we assume ; only slight modifications are required for .
